juggle.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to keep three or more objects moving through the air by throwing and catching them very quickly
juggle.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: One guy was juggling with five balls.
juggle.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to try to fit two or more jobs, activities etc into your life, especially with difficulty
juggle.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Itâ€™s hard trying to juggle a job with kids and the housework.
juggle.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to change things or arrange them in the way you want, or in a way that makes it possible for you to do something
juggle.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: If I juggle these appointments around, I can fit you in.
juggle.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to buy and sell different investments frequently in order to make as much profit as possible
juggle.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Traders juggle stock and options to maximize profits from temporary price differences.
Some investors juggle between stocks, bonds and cash in search of high returns with moderate risks.
juggle.translation[1].definitions[1].def: if you juggle numbers or figures, you present them in a different way so that they show different things or have a different effect
juggle.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: After juggling the figures, the Commerce Department now says GNP rose by only 1.4% in the third quarter.
juggle.translation[1].definitions[2].def: if you juggle two jobs or activities, you try to fit them both into your life
juggle.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: Many women successfully juggle career and family.
